Abandoned

Used as initial commit for https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/tree/vue3
These are new tests that we don't currently pass;  They're disabled for now until someone can debug them.
BootsrapVue may be a blocker for this change. Currently BootstrapVue only supports Vue 2. I don't know when Vue 3 support comes out. This is why the we paused the migration efforts
https://bootstrap-vue.org/docs

Bootstrap-vue isn't properly supported by vue-3 just yet.
Moreover, the change from vue2 to vue 3 requires a lot of talk over
as things like how templates, emits work is different in vue3

Also, even though options API is still there, Composition API is introduced.
And one more thing that concerns me the most is how the lifecycle changed semi-dramatically.

I added an issue the community help wanted project board to track this discussion

https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/issues/95

I see a couple options here:
1. point npm to the git PR https://github.com/bootstrap-vue/bootstrap-vue/pull/6905
2. Try to use bootstrap-vue-3
https://www.npmjs.com/package/bootstrap-vue-3

Dixie pointed out the same thing about vue-bootstrap, I replied there, lets keep that discussion in one thread.

> Moreover, the change from vue2 to vue 3 requires a lot of talk over
as things like how templates, emits work is different in vue3

Can you point to any docs on how vue3 handles emit differently?  I see some mention of a new "emits" property that seems to be optional on components.  We could make use of that later it looks like, but in terms of porting, it doesn't look like anything in our code needs to change?

How do templates differ?  I see a couple changing ones:
"Change of precedence when using v-if and v-for on the same element (template Ddrectives)"

I don't see any place where we use v-if and v-for on the same element, so we should be safe there (I think)

Anything else that's important?

I see a lot of "should" style advice, but for anything that's optional best practices, I think the right approach is to get the minimum we need, get it merged, then we can start working on the best practices in the priority that they're important to the project to get the security issues mitigated.
Didn't mean to resolve.  What's the preference from the maintainers?
I wasn't sure if this was right, but it seemed to make the compiler happy.
This is where I left off.
Done
TO anyone watching this, I'm having trouble with scss not getting applied, which is pretty easy to see, but the UI loads.

Have tried to run PR in local, was getting multiple errors after resolving some of them got error at i18n package (proxy set handler returned false for property '"$n"'), upgraded i18nversion.
With the migration build,
we can get multiple error and might try to resolve each error. We are not sure how many will come and are we fixing those errors in correct way!
BootstrapVue is not supported in vue3, After removing @vue/compact, We need to move to Bootstrap Vue-next.

> Have tried to run PR in local, was getting multiple errors after resolving some of them got error at i18n package (proxy set handler returned false for property '"$n"'), upgraded i18nversion.

Note, that this error shows up on the login page, and only shows up in development mode.  When loaded on the bmc, this error doesn't seem to present anymore.  This is one of the things that needs debugged at some point.

> With the migration build,
> we can get multiple error and might try to resolve each error. We are not sure how many will come and are we fixing those errors in correct way!

There's pretty heavy documentation on each warning, and how to move it forward.  I agree, it's a difficult problem, but we certainly can't rewrite the webui in a single patch, and attempting it means that nobody else can contribute while the vue3 change is happening, which I suspect is part of what has stalled this transition for so long (among other things).

> BootstrapVue is not supported in vue3, After removing @vue/compact, We need to move to Bootstrap Vue-next.

I'm assuming you mean @vue/compat.  We should drop the vue-bootstrap dependencies alltogether, and use the default css from the bootstrap project.  Bootstrap 5 has dropped the jquery dependency, so there's no real reason for us to pull in any bootstrap vue specific module anymore.  Breaking this need for a vue specific bootstrap module will help us a lot in the long run if we decide we want to move to another framework, react, server-side rendering, or all manner of things.
This is getting to the point where folks can start playing around with it and fixing stuff.  I wonder if putting this on a branch would be a good idea?
You plan to add back bootstrap?

The tests need looked at.  What's here was me attempting to get them passing again using the advice from vue/test-utils, but it only worked in some cases.

Yes, it should be brought back once we figure out the errors.
Surya, can you please stack another patch on top rather than rewriting this patch?

I've opened up your changes to be reviewed separately here:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/webui-vue/+/72552/2
If my changes are in separate PR how the code changes will be in sync with PR #55438?
they’ll merge to the vue3 branch once it’s created.
@Ed, For next code changes, he has to create new PR like PR#72552 or he has to push code changes to existing PR#72552. ? please clarify.
Generally you would create a new PR.
Abandon this?
Since in the vue3 branch
